column1: TA2.38;The EU offshore Renewable Energy Strategy. Assessment: In 2023
column2: the cumulative installed capacity for wind offshore was on the order of 19 GW;TA4.3;+;The increase in offshore wind capacity is likely to have a positive impact on the reduction of GHG emissions in the transport sector
column3: as offshore wind can provide a source of renewable energy for the production of green hydrogen
column4: which can be used as a low-carbon fuel in the transport sector. This connection is based on the context of the report
column5: which highlights the importance of renewable energy in reducing GHG emissions.

column1: TA2.39;The strategy sets targets for an installed capacity of at least 1 GW of ocean energy by 2030 and 40 GW by 2050;TA4.5;+;The development of ocean energy is likely to have a positive impact on the use of Sustainable Aviation Fuels (SAF) in the aviation sector
column2: as ocean energy can provide a source of renewable energy for the production of SAF. This connection is based on the context of the report
column3: which highlights the importance of renewable energy in reducing GHG emissions in the transport sector.

column1: TA2.40;Around 30% of EU primary steel production is expected to be decarbonised on the basis of renewable hydrogen.;TA4.20;+;The decarbonization of steel production through the use of renewable hydrogen is likely to have a positive impact on the production of renewable hydrogen electrolysers
column2: as the demand for renewable hydrogen in the steel sector can drive the development of this technology. This connection is based on the context of the report
column3: which highlights the importance of renewable hydrogen in decarbonizing industry.

column1: TA3.1;Halve the amount of residual (non-recycled) municipal waste by 2030;TA3.13;+;The reduction of residual municipal waste is likely to have a positive impact on the recycling capacity of the EU
column2: as reducing waste can increase the availability of materials for recycling. This connection is based on the context of the report
column3: which highlights the importance of recycling in reducing waste and promoting a circular economy.

column1: TA3.3;Double EU’s circular material use rate in the coming decade;TA3.12;+;The increase in circular material use rate is likely to have a positive impact on the development of manufacturing capacity in the EU for strategic net-zero technologies
column2: as the use of recycled materials can reduce the demand for primary materials and promote a circular economy. This connection is based on the context of the report
column3: which highlights the importance of recycling and circular economy in reducing waste and promoting sustainable development.

column2: Union extraction capacity should be able of extracting the ores

column2: Union processing capacity
column3: including for all intermediate processing steps
column4: should be able of producing at least 40% of the Union’s annual consumption of strategic raw materials;TA3.11;+;The development of processing capacity for strategic raw materials is likely to have a positive impact on the diversification of imports of these materials

column1: TA3.11;Diversify the Union’s imports of strategic raw materials with a view to ensuring that
column3: the Union’s annual consumption of each strategic raw material at any relevant stage of processing can rely on imports from several third countries or from overseas countries or territories (OCTs) and that no third country accounts for more than 65% of the Union’s annual consumption of such a strategic raw material;TA3.15;+;The diversification of imports of strategic raw materials is likely to have a positive impact on the development of recycling technologies for batteries
column4: as the availability of recycled materials can reduce dependence on primary materials and promote a circular economy. This connection is based on the context of the report

column2: manufacturing capacity in the Union of the strategic net-zero technologies listed in the Annex approaches or reaches a benchmark of at least 40% of the Union’s annual deployment needs;TA4.13;+;The development of manufacturing capacity for strategic net-zero technologies is likely to have a positive impact on the reduction of GHG emissions in the transport sector

column2: Union recycling capacity
column3: including for all intermediate recycling steps

column5: as the availability of recycling technologies can drive the development of collection systems. This connection is based on the context of the report

column1: TA3.19;Any natural or legal person that places on the market products incorporating portable batteries shall ensure that those batteries are readily removable and replaceable by the end-user at any time during the lifetime of the product;TA3.22;+;The development of design for recyclability of products is likely to have a positive impact on the recovery of materials from waste
column2: as the availability of removable and replaceable batteries can drive the development of recycling technologies. This connection is based on the context of the report
column3: which highlights the importance of recycling and circular economy in reducing waste and promoting sustainable development.

column1: TA3.20;Recycling shall achieve at least the following targets for recycling efficiency: No later than 31 December 2025 - 75% by average weight of lead-acid batteries; - 80% by average weight of nickel-cadmium batteries - 50% by average weight of other waste batteries;TA3.21;+;The development of recycling efficiency targets for batteries is likely to have a positive impact on the recycling efficiency of lithium-based batteries
column2: as the availability of recycled materials can drive the development of recycling technologies. This connection is based on the context of the report
column3: which highlights the importance of recycling and circular economy in reducing waste and promoting sustainable development.

column1: TA4.3;The yearly average GHG intensity of the energy used on board by a ship during a reporting period shall be reduced
column2: compared to the reference value (91.16 gCO2e/MJ) by: 2% from 1 January 2025; 6% from 1 January 2030; 14.5% from 1 January 2035; 31% from 1 January 2040; 62% from 1 January 2045; 80% from 1 January 2050.;TA2.38;-;The reduction of GHG intensity in the shipping sector is likely to have a negative impact on the development of offshore wind energy
column3: as the increased efficiency of shipping can reduce the demand for offshore wind energy. This connection is based on the context of the report
column4: which highlights the importance of reducing GHG emissions in the transport sector.

column1: TA4.5;Aviation fuel suppliers shall also ensure that Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) made available to aircraft operators at each Union airport will be at least 2% from 2025
column2: 6% from 2030
column5: 42% from 2045 and 70% from 2050.;TA3.9;-;The development of SAF is likely to have a negative impact on the processing capacity for strategic raw materials
column6: as the demand for SAF can drive the demand for primary materials and reduce the availability of materials for processing. This connection is based on the context of the report
column7: which highlights the importance of strategic raw materials in promoting a circular economy and reducing dependence on imports.

column1: TA4.7;Each Member State shall set an obligation on fuel suppliers to ensure that: (B) the combined share of advanced biofuels and biogas produced from the feedstock listed in Part A of Annex IX and of renewable fuels of non-biological origin in the energy supplied to the transport sector is at least 1% in 2025 and 5.5% in 2030
column2: of which a share of at least 1 percentage point is from renewable fuels of non-biological origin in 2030.;TA3.13;+;The development of advanced biofuels and renewable fuels of non-biological origin is likely to have a positive impact on the recycling capacity of the EU
column3: as the availability of these fuels can drive the development of recycling technologies for batteries and other products. This connection is based on the context of the report
column4: which highlights the importance of recycling and circular economy in reducing waste and promoting sustainable development.

column1: TA4.8;Member States with maritime ports shall endeavour to ensure that as of 2030 the share of renewable fuels of non-biological origin (RFNBOs) in the total amount of energy supplied to the maritime transport sector is at least 1.2%.;TA3.11;-;The development of RFNBOs is likely to have a negative impact on the diversification of imports of strategic raw materials
column2: as the demand for RFNBOs can drive the demand for primary materials and reduce the availability of materials for diversification. This connection is based on the context of the report
column3: which highlights the importance of strategic raw materials in promoting a circular economy and reducing dependence on imports.

column1: TA4.9;Cut the emissions of transport sector by 90% by 2050 relative to 1990.;TA2.40;+;The reduction of emissions in the transport sector is likely to have a positive impact on the decarbonization of steel production
column2: as the demand for low-carbon steel can drive the development of decarbonized steel production technologies. This connection is based on the context of the report
column3: which highlights the importance of reducing GHG emissions in the transport sector.

column1: TA4.10;EU fisheries are encouraged to continue the positive trend
column2: as observed for the period 2009-2019

column4: as the increased efficiency of fisheries can reduce the demand for these materials. This connection is based on the context of the report
column5: which highlights the importance of strategic raw materials in promoting a circular economy and reducing dependence on imports.

column1: TA4.11;Reduce the average door-to-door cost of combined transport operations by at least 10% within 7 years;TA4.13;+;The reduction of costs in the transport sector is likely to have a positive impact on the development of intermodal transport

column3: which highlights the importance of reducing costs and increasing efficiency in the transport sector.

column1: TA4.13;For [...] “urban buses” manufacturers shall comply with the 90% (in the reporting period 2030-2034) and 100% (as from 2035) minimum shares in their fleet of new heavy-duty vehicles;TA4.15;+;The development of zero-emission urban buses is likely to have a positive impact on the reduction of emissions in the transport sector

column4: 4-LH

column1: TA4.18;The share of biofuels and biogas produced from the feedstock listed in Part B of Annex IX in the energy content of fuels and electricity supplied to the transport sector shall

column1: TA4.19;The yearly quantity of aviation fuel uplifted by a given aircraft operator at a given Union airport shall be at least 90% of the yearly aviation fuel required

column1: TA4.25;Member States shall ensure that
column2: at the end of each year
column3: the following power output targets are met cumulatively: (a) for each light-duty battery electric vehicle registered in their territory

column5: a total power output of at least 0.80 kW is provided through publicly accessible recharging stations.;TA4.13;+;The development of recharging infrastructure is likely to have a positive impact on the development of intermodal transport
